text.p: Rheometric Scientific Inc said Friday the significant write-offs it took in 1996 will have a direct affect on improving the quality of its earnings beginning in 1997.

The maker of materials testing instruments and systems issued the statement as it reported that various non-recurring charges, totaling $4.8 million, contributed to a net loss of approximately $6.3 million or $0.48 per share for 1996.
"Management does not believe that the company's 1996 financial performance is representative of what the company can accomplish in terms of improved profitability and market growth, it said.
At the same time, the company reported revenues of $41.1 million for 1996, down a bit from $41.2 million for 1995.
Revenue growth in previous years was interrupted by delays in product introduction, it said.

It noted, however, that the successful introduction of redesigned thermal analysis products and the Windows 95 RSI Orchestrator software in late 1996 provides a "high degree of confidence" that these products will be highly competitive.
The company said it will introduce in mid-1997 a totally redesigned stress rheometer and complete during the year the redesign of its simultaneous thermal analyzer.
